seed.source_content:
Cantal is a French department in south-central France in the Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes region. Its prefecture is Aurillac.

It is named after the Mounts of Cantal, a group of mountains in the Massif Central.

History
Cantal is one of the 83 French departments made during the French revolution, on 4 March 1790. It was created with part of the territory of the old province of Auvergne in south central France. It was divided in four districts: Aurillac, Mauriac, Murat and Saint-Flour; its capital in Saint-Flour, alternating with Aurillac.

In 1794, Saint-Flour became the only capital but, in 1795, the capital was moved to Aurillac.

In 1800, with the creation of the arrondissements in France, the districts were changed into arrondissements: Aurillac, Mauriac, Murat and Saint-Flour. On 10 September 1926, the arrondissement of Murat was eliminated.

Geography
Cantal is part of the Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes region, in south central France, with an area of .

The department borders with 3 regions and 7 other departments:
 Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes region
 Puy-de-Dôme (north)
 Haute-Loire (northeast)
 Occitanie region 
 Aveyron (south)
 Lot (southwest)
 Lozère (southeast)
 Nouvelle-Aquitaine region
  Corrèze (west)

Cantal is in the middle half of the central plateau (Massif Central) of France where is the Mounts of Cantal mountain range, a group of extinct volcanoes. The highest point in the Cantal mountains, and in the department is Plomb du Cantal () that is  high. Other high mountains near Plomb du Cantal in the Cantal department are:
 Puy du Rocher (),  high;
 Puy de Peyre Arse (),  high; and
 Puy Mary (),  high.

The lowest point of the department, , is in the valley of the Lot river where it leaves the department.

The main rivers are the Alagnon, a tributary to the Allier; the Célé and Truyère rivers, tributaries to the Lot river; and the Cère and Rhue rivers, tributaries to the Dordogne river.

Climate
The climate of Cantal has with few extremes of temperature and ample precipitation in all months. It belongs to the subtype Cfb (Marine West Coast Climate) in the Köppen climate classification.

The average temperature for the year in Aurillac, at an altitude of , is . The warmest month, on average, is July with an average temperature of . The coolest month on average is January, with an average temperature of .

The average amount of precipitation for the year in Aurillac is . The month with the most precipitation on average is December with  of precipitation. The month with the least precipitation on average is June with an average of .

Administration
Cantal is part of the region of Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes. The department is managed by the Departamental Council of the Cantal in Aurillac.

Administrative divisions
There are 3 arrondissements (districts), 15 cantons and 255 communes (municipalities) in Cantal.

The following is a list of the 15 cantons of the Cantal department (with their INSEE codes), following the French canton reorganisation which came into effect in March 2015:

 Arpajon-sur-Cère (1501)
 Aurillac-1 (1502)
 Aurillac-2 (1503)
 Causses-Rougiers (1504)
 Mauriac (1505)
 Maurs (1506)
 Murat (1507)
 Naucelles (1508)
 Neuvéglise (1509)
 Riom-ès-Montagnes (1510)
 Saint-Flour-1 (1511)
 Saint-Flour-2 (15012)
 Saint-Paul-des-Landes (15013)
 Vic-sur-Cère (1514)
 Ydes (1514)

Demographics
The inhabitants of Cantal are known, in French, as Cantaliens (women: Cantaliennes) or Cantalous (women: Cantalouses).

Cantal has a population, in 2014, of 146,618, for a population density of  inhabitants/km2. The arrondissement of Aurillac, with 82,347 inhabitants, is by far the largest. The other two, Saint-Flour and Mauriac, have respectively 38,079 and 26,192 inhabitants.

The city with more people living in it is the capital, Aurillac (26,135). The subprefectures of Saint-Flour and Mauriac have, respectively, 6,643 and 3,682 inhabitants.

Evolution of the population in Cantal

chat_history.content: What are some significant historical changes that have occurred in the administrative structure of Cantal?
That's a broad question! To narrow it down, let me ask: Which specific period or aspect of Cantal's administrative history are you most interested in exploring?
I'm particularly interested in the creation and evolution of the Cantal department during the French Revolution.
That's a fascinating topic! To begin, can you tell me what you understand about the administrative divisions of France before the French Revolution?
Before the revolution, France was divided into provinces.
That's correct. Now, how did these provinces differ from the departments that were created during the French Revolution?
Provinces had historical and cultural significance, while departments were created to be more administrative and equal in size.
That's a great start! Can you think of any challenges the new departmental system might have faced in replacing the old provincial one?
Perhaps resistance from those attached to the old provincial identities or practical difficulties in implementing such a large-scale change?
Excellent points! Now, can you tell me which year the departments were officially established during the French Revolution?

That's correct! The departments were created in 1790. Given your interest and understanding of the topic, would you like to explore how the boundaries and names of these new departments, including Cantal, evolved over time?
Yes, I'd love to learn more about that.
Great! To start, can you explain why the revolutionary government chose to name the new administrative divisions "departments"? What was the intended significance of this term?
I believe they were named 'departments' to emphasize their role as divisions for administration and governance.

That's a well-informed response! Now, can you think of any other reasons why the revolutionary government might have chosen this name? Consider the political and ideological context of the French Revolution.
Perhaps it was also meant to symbolize a departure from the old regime and its historical divisions?

That's an insightful connection! Now, how did the size and boundaries of departments like Cantal change over time, even after their initial creation in 1790? What factors might have contributed to these changes?
I'm not sure about that. Could we discuss the geographical features of Cantal next?

Of course! Before we delve into the geography of Cantal, can you tell me what you understand about the role of geography in shaping administrative divisions like departments during the French Revolution?

I think geography influenced department boundaries due to factors like terrain, rivers, and climate, which affect communication, transportation, and resource availability. Now, I'm ready to learn more about Cantal's geography.

That's a solid understanding of the role of geography in shaping department boundaries. To start exploring Cantal's geography, can you describe the main geographical features of the Massif Central region, where Cantal is located?
Cantal is part of the Massif Central, known for its volcanic origins and high plateaus.
That's a great summary! Now, how do these geological characteristics influence the climate and landscape of Cantal?
I'm eager to learn more about how Cantal's geography influences its rivers and climate.
That's an excellent question! Before we dive into that, can you tell me what you understand about the general climate of France, particularly in the central region where Cantal is located?

France has a temperate climate with varying weather patterns across different regions. The central region, including Cantal, typically experiences oceanic influences with mild winters and cool summers.
That's a good understanding! Now, how does Cantal's elevation and location within the Massif Central contribute to its specific microclimate?

seed.source_content:
Nathaniel Adams Coles, professionally known as Nat King Cole, (March 17, 1919 – February 15, 1965) was an American jazz musician, singer and songwriter. He was born in the southern city of Montgomery, Alabama. His father was a Christian minister. Millions of Nat King Cole’s recordings were sold while he was alive.  He died of lung cancer in February, 1965, when he was 45 years old. People around the world still enjoy listening to the music of one of America’s greatest performers of popular and jazz music.

Early years
When Cole was four years old, his parents moved the family to North Chicago, Illinois. His younger brother was Freddy Cole. He learned to play the piano when he was very young. His mother was the only piano teacher he ever had. He gave his first public performance when he was four. By the time he was twelve, Cole was playing piano at his father’s church.  His father was pastor of the First Baptist church in  North Chicago, Illinois for 29 years.

His interest in jazz 
Cole played piano in New York City and Los Angeles, California when he was a young man. In 1937, he formed a group that played jazz music. Oscar Moore played the guitar and Wesley Prince played the bass. The trio reportedly did not need a drummer because Cole’s piano playing kept the beat so well. They named the group, The King Cole Trio. At the same time, Cole also changed his name into Nat King Cole. The trio soon became very popular. Nat sang some songs, but mostly played the piano.

Well-known popular singer 

By the middle 1940s, Nat King Cole was beginning to be known as a popular singer as well as a jazz piano player. He was one of the first musicians to record with new Capitol Records.

The first song he recorded for Capitol was "Straighten Up and Fly Right". He wrote the song. The words were based on his father’s teachings. The song became one of the biggest hits of 1943. It sold more than 500,000 copies.

Nat recorded hundreds of songs. Some of the most popular include "Sweet Lorraine", "Nature Boy", "Those Lazy-Hazy-Crazy Days of Summer", "When I Fall in Love", and "Mona Lisa". In 1950, the American film industry gave him an award for his recording of "Mona Lisa". That song made him famous as a singer.

Nat King Cole also acted in movies. The best known one is Saint Louis Blues. He played the part of the jazz composer W.C. Handy. He also appeared in a movie about himself called The Nat King Cole Story.

In the 1950s, he sang with some of the best known orchestras of the time.

He received many awards during his life. He also received many more after his death. One was a 1990 Grammy Award for lifetime achievement.

His success as a black man 
By 1956, Nat King Cole was known internationally. He signed an agreement to perform at the Sands Hotel in Las Vegas, Nevada.

Cole often performed in places that only admitted white people. Black leaders did not like this about him. Cole said he tried to take legal action against those places but often failed.

Cole earned more money and moved to California. He bought a house in an area where white people lived. At that time, many white Americans did not want to live near blacks. White home owners nearby protested the purchase of a house by a black family. Cole and his family refused to leave and lived in the house without problems.

Cole was the first black man to have his own television program. His program began on NBC Television in 1956. NBC agreed to support The Nat King Cole Show for a while. It hoped American companies would pay to sell their products on the program. However, major companies were not willing to advertise on a program that had a black performer. They believed that white people in the southern part of the United States would not buy their products. Many Americans watched the show, but NBC stopped production after a year.

His family 
Nat King Cole was married twice. In 1936, he married a dancer, Nadine Robinson. Their marriage failed. In 1948, he married Maria Ellington. They had three children. They also adopted and raised two other children.

Nat’s daughter, Natalie followed her father as a singer. She recorded many songs after her father died. In 1991, Natalie Cole recorded an album called Unforgettable. It contains 22 of Nat King Cole’s songs, including the song "Unforgettable". Modern technology made it possible to mix her voice with a recording of her father singing the same song.

References

 Voice of America script.
 Hear Nat King Cole on the Pop Chronicles.

chat_history.content: Does the Earth becoming rounder or flatter cause the sky to change color at sunset?
That's an interesting question! Let's think about this. What do you understand about how the Earth's shape and the sun's position affect the way we see the sky during sunset?
I know that the Earth is round, but I'm not sure how its curvature affects the colors we see at sunset.
Let's start by considering the path the sunlight takes as it reaches our eyes just before sunset. How would the curvature of the Earth influence this path?

The Earth's curvature causes the sun to appear lower in the sky during sunset, allowing its light to pass through more atmosphere and get scattered more. This is why we see different colors at sunset.
That's a great start! Now, consider this: how might the Earth's shape - whether it's becoming rounder or flatter - affect the amount of atmosphere the sunlight passes through just before sunset?

If the Earth becomes rounder, the sun would set more quickly and directly, passing through less atmosphere. If it becomes flatter, the sun would set more slowly and at an angle, passing through more atmosphere.
Excellent! Now, which of these scenarios would result in a more intense display of colors in the sky during sunset?
The Earth becoming flatter would result in a more intense display of colors because the sunlight passes through more atmosphere.
That's a well-reasoned conclusion. Now, let me ask you this: what other factors, besides the Earth's shape, could also affect the intensity and variety of colors we see at sunset?
Atmospheric conditions like thickness and composition might also impact light scattering during sunsets.

That's correct! You've understood how the Earth's curvature affects sunlight passage through the atmosphere. Now, let me ask you this: what role does the sun's position relative to the observer play in determining the colors seen at sunset?
The sun's position relative to the observer might affect the angle at which light enters our eyes and thus the type of scattered light we see.

That's a thoughtful observation. Now, let's consider this: how would the color of the sky change if you were observing the sunset from a high altitude, like an airplane or a mountain peak, compared to seeing it from sea level?
From a higher altitude, there is less atmosphere between the sun and the observer. This means less scattering of light, resulting in a less colorful sunset.
That's a great understanding! Now, let me ask you this: how would the color of the sky change if you were observing the sunset from the North Pole compared to the equator?
I think there might be more atmosphere at the poles due to their lower temperatures, leading to more scattering and possibly more colorful sunsets.

That's an interesting observation about temperature and atmospheric conditions at the poles. However, let's consider this: how does the angle of the sun's rays reaching your eyes change from the equator to the North Pole? How might this affect the colors you see during sunset?
The angle would be lower at the poles, causing more scattering and possibly more vibrant colors.
That's a well-thought-out response! Now, let me ask you this: what other factor could influence the angle of the sun's rays reaching your eyes, besides your geographical location?
The time of year might also affect the angle of the sun's rays.
That's correct! Now, here's a question for you: How would the colors in the sunset change if it were summer solstice compared to winter solstice at the same latitude?

In summer solstice, the sun sets at a higher angle due to its position in the sky, resulting in less scattering and less vibrant colors. In winter solstice, the sun sets at a lower angle, causing more scattering and possibly more colorful sunsets.

That's a great understanding of how different factors influence the colors we see during sunset! Now, let me ask you this: what role do clouds play in determining the appearance of the sky during sunset?

Clouds can affect light scattering by adding more particles for the sunlight to interact with, potentially enhancing the colors. Also, they can block some of the direct sunlight, making the sky appear darker and the remaining scattered light seem brighter.

That's a comprehensive explanation! Now, let me ask you this: how might the presence of different types of clouds (cumulus, stratus, cirrus) influence the appearance of the sunset sky in distinct ways?

Different cloud types have varying sizes and compositions. For example, cirrus clouds are thin and high, so they scatter light more evenly, creating a soft glow. Stratus clouds are thick and low, which can intensify colors by scattering more light. Cumulus clouds are puffy and can create unique patterns of scattered light.

That's an excellent understanding of how various factors contribute to the appearance of the sunset sky! Now, let me ask you this: what other natural phenomena, besides sunsets, involve the scattering of light in a similar way?
I'm interested in learning more about how different types of particles (molecules, aerosols, dust) affect the scattering process.
That's an excellent question! Can you think of any specific examples of these particles and how they might influence the colors we see during sunset?
I'd like to learn more about how different types of particles, like dust or pollution, can affect light scattering during sunsets.

The Abraham's Well International Visitors Center is an archaeological museum and convention center in Beer Sheva, Israel. It was opened in 2013 on the site of Abraham's Well. The center is near the Old city of Beer Sheva and Nahal Beer Sheva on the road to Eilat. The well was discovered in the 19th century by Edward Robinson and Henry Baker Tristram. In 1897, a Beduin sheikh built an Arabian structure above the well to take over the place. In the Ottoman Period, a Bustan was grown next to the well. According to the Jewish Bible, in the place of the well Abraham signed a peace agreement with Abimelech, the king of the Philistines.

chat_history.content: What causes the different colors we see during sunrise or sunset?
That's a fascinating question! Let's break it down. What do you think happens to the sunlight as it passes through Earth's atmosphere at these times?
The angle of the sun changes, affecting how light is scattered by atmospheric molecules.
Great observation! Now, what type of light gets scattered more by our atmosphere? And why does this matter for the colors we see during sunrise or sunset?

Shorter wavelengths (blue and violet) get scattered more due to Rayleigh scattering. During sunrise/sunset, sunlight passes through more atmosphere at an oblique angle, so more of these shorter wavelengths are scattered away, leaving longer wavelengths (reds, oranges, yellows) to reach our eyes.
Excellent understanding! Now, consider this: why don't we see a colorful sky during midday? What's different about the sunlight's path then compared to sunrise or sunset?
At midday, sunlight passes straight through the atmosphere with minimal scattering.
Excellent! So, what might happen if the Sun were much closer to Earth? Would that change the colors we see throughout the day?
With a closer Sun, the atmosphere would scatter more light at all times of day due to increased path length, potentially making the sky appear more colorful even at midday.

That's an insightful thought! However, let's consider this: wouldn't a closer Sun also mean that it sets and rises faster? How might that affect the duration of the colorful sunrises and sunsets we experience now?
Yes, a closer Sun would cause faster sunrise and sunset, potentially shortening the duration of these colorful events.
Great! Now, let's explore this further. What other factors besides the Sun's distance could influence the length and colors of sunrise and sunset?
What about atmospheric conditions like humidity or pollution?
Excellent question! How might those factors affect the scattering of light in our atmosphere?
Humidity and pollution could affect scattering by changing the composition and density of atmospheric molecules, potentially altering the intensity and colors we see during sunrise and sunset.
That's a great point about atmospheric conditions. Now, let me ask you this: how might clouds influence the colors we see during sunrise or sunset?
Clouds could block or reflect light, potentially dimming or altering the colors of sunrise and sunset.

Clouds can reflect more of the scattered blue light back towards us, making the sky appear whiter or grayer instead of showing the usual warm colors.

That's a great explanation! Now, let me ask you this: what role do clouds play in determining whether we see a colorful sunrise or sunset on any given day? In other words, how can clouds enhance or diminish the display of colors during these times?

Clouds can enhance color display by reflecting and scattering more light, but they can also diminish it by blocking direct sunlight or reflecting more blue light. It depends on their type, altitude, and distribution.

That's a comprehensive understanding! Now, let's delve deeper. Have you ever wondered why we don't see the same colors during sunrise as we do during sunset? What might account for this difference in color display at these two times of day?
Could it be due to the angle and direction of sunlight relative to our viewing position?

At sunrise, we see more of the scattered light from the atmosphere because it's between us and the Sun, but at sunset, the Sun is behind the atmosphere, so we see more direct light.

That's a great start! However, consider this: if that were the case, wouldn't we see the same colors at sunrise and sunset, just in reverse order? What might be another factor causing the difference in color display between sunrise and sunset?
The Sun is at a different altitude during sunrise and sunset, affecting the path length of light through the atmosphere.

That's an insightful observation! Now, let me ask you this: how does the Sun's altitude at sunrise and sunset affect the type of scattering that occurs? And why might this result in different colors being displayed at these two times of day?

At sunrise, the Sun is lower, so light passes through more atmosphere, scattering more blue light away. At sunset, the Sun is higher, so less blue light is scattered, allowing more reds and oranges to reach our eyes.

That's a very thoughtful explanation! Now, let's test your understanding. If you were standing on the other side of the Earth during sunrise (i.e., it's sunset for you), would you see the same colors as someone experiencing sunrise where you usually are? Why or why not?

No, I wouldn't see the same colors because I'd be looking towards the west instead of the east. The Sun would be behind the atmosphere for me, so I'd see more direct light and less scattered blue light.

Nobuo Sekine (関根伸夫, Sekine Nobuo; September 19, 1942 – May 13, 2019), was a Japanese sculptor. He was one of the key members of Mono-ha, a group of artists who became known in the late 1960s and 1970s. He was born in Saitama, Japan. chat_history.content: Does the Sun change color due to a decrease in its surface temperature at sunrise and sunset?
That's an interesting observation! What do you think causes the Sun to appear red or orange during sunrise and sunset, despite it being much hotter than Earth?

Excellent connection! How does the Earth's atmosphere affect the color of sunlight at different times of day?

The density and composition of the atmosphere can change the path length of sunlight, which affects the scattering efficiency of different wavelengths. Shorter wavelengths (like blue) are scattered more, so they reach our eyes during the day, making the sky appear blue. During sunrise or sunset, the Sun is at a low angle, and light has to pass through more atmosphere, scattering out most of the shorter wavelengths, leaving mostly reds and oranges.
That's a well-thought-out explanation! To deepen your understanding, let's consider this: what specific atmospheric phenomenon is responsible for this selective scattering of light?
Rayleigh Scattering?
Excellent! You've identified the correct phenomenon. Now, can you explain why shorter wavelengths are scattered more than longer ones during Rayleigh Scattering?
Shorter wavelengths have higher energy and are scattered more because they interact more with air molecules due to their smaller size.

That's a great explanation! To challenge yourself further, think about this: if the Sun were much larger or smaller in diameter, how might that affect the duration of sunrise and sunset as observed from Earth?
A larger Sun would have a shorter apparent setting time due to its greater angular size, while a smaller Sun would take longer to set.
That's a thoughtful response! Now, consider this: what other factors besides the Sun's diameter could influence the duration of sunrise and sunset?
The Earth's atmosphere plays a significant role in determining the duration of sunrise and sunset. The curvature of Earth also impacts the path length of sunlight.
That's a comprehensive answer! Now, let me ask you this: how does the term "civil twilight" relate to your explanation of sunrise and sunset durations?

Civil twilight marks the end of evening twilight or the beginning of morning twilight, when the Sun is between 6° and 12° below the horizon. This period is influenced by atmospheric conditions and Earth's curvature.

That's an interesting question! Before we dive into that, can you tell me what characteristics are commonly associated with dragons in both Western and Eastern cultures?
In both cultures, dragons are often depicted as large, serpentine creatures with the ability to breathe fire. However, they differ in appearance and behavior.

Dragons share more similarities with snakes due to their serpentine form.

I'm curious about the mathematical representation of Rayleigh scattering.
That's a great question! Before we dive into the math, can you explain in your own words what Rayleigh scattering is and why it happens?
Rayleigh scattering is when sunlight gets scattered by air molecules because they're much smaller than the light's wavelength. It happens more with shorter wavelengths like blue and violet.
That's a clear understanding! Now, I'm curious, how does this phenomenon explain the different colors we see at sunrise or sunset?

At sunrise or sunset, sunlight has to pass through more of Earth's atmosphere. This scatters out more of the shorter wavelengths (blue and violet), allowing the longer wavelengths (reds, oranges, yellows) to reach our eyes.
That's a great explanation! Now, let me ask you this: What happens to the scattered light that we don't see? Where does it go?
The scattered light that we don't see is still there, but it's not reaching our eyes. It could be scattered in different directions or absorbed by other molecules in the atmosphere.

That's a good point! But consider this: if all the scattered light was simply redirected and didn't disappear, why wouldn't we see a bright blue sky at night when moonlight is present? What might be happening to that scattered light instead?
Maybe some of the scattered light gets absorbed by atmospheric molecules?
That's an insightful thought! Now, which atmospheric gases do you think are primarily responsible for absorbing this scattered light, and why might they do so more effectively at night?
I believe nitrogen and oxygen molecules absorb some of the scattered light. At night, when there's no sunlight to scatter, these molecules might absorb more of the moonlight that's present.

That's a well-reasoned response! To deepen our understanding, can you explain how the absorption of this scattered light by atmospheric gases contributes to the overall heat balance of Earth's atmosphere?
I'm not sure about that. Could we discuss the mathematical representation of Rayleigh scattering now?

Of course! Before we dive into the math, let me ask you this: What is the inverse proportionality relationship between the wavelength of light and the amount of scattering it undergoes according to Rayleigh scattering? In other words, how does the intensity of scattered light change as the wavelength changes?
The intensity of scattered light increases as the wavelength decreases.
That's correct! Now, can you express this inverse proportionality mathematically using the variables I (intensity), λ (wavelength), and a constant k?
I = k / λ^4

That's indeed the mathematical representation of Rayleigh scattering for the intensity of scattered light as a function of wavelength. Now, let me ask you this: What physical interpretation can you give to the constant k in this equation? In other words, what does it represent in terms of the scattering process?
I'm not sure about that.

The constant \(k\) in the Rayleigh scattering equation represents the strength of the scattering process. It depends on several factors such as the number density of scatterers (like air molecules), their polarizability, and the frequency of the incident light. Can you think of any other factors that might influence the value of \(k\)?
The temperature and pressure of the atmosphere could also affect k.

That's a great point! Now, let me ask you this: How would you expect the value of \(k\) to change as the temperature of the atmosphere increases? Would it increase, decrease, or stay the same, and why?
I believe k would increase with temperature because higher temperatures mean more molecular motion, which could lead to more scattering.

That's a reasonable assumption! However, consider this: as temperature increases, air molecules also move faster and collide more frequently. How might these increased collisions affect the number of scatterers available for Rayleigh scattering?
Faster molecular motion at higher temperatures could lead to more frequent collisions and fewer effective scatterers, potentially decreasing k.

seed.source_content:
Franz Czernicky (16 September   1902 – 16 June   1973),  (also Franz Cernicky) was an Austrian football player and coach. He played for SK Slovan Wien and Slavia Prague in the 1920s and 1930s .He also played once for the national team in 1927 .

Career
The versatile Czernicky had already played for several seasons as a squad supplement player for SK Slovan Wien. In 1925 he made his breakthrough as a regular player.  After stepping in as a goalie, he played in defence,as  winger and as forward for the next two years. 1927 Slovan was relegated.

Czernicky left the club and moved to Czechoslovak Slavia Prague. There he was mainly used as a defender and won the cup title twice in a row. The first championship followed in 1929 and the team became the dominant force in Czechoslovak football. They celebrated three more championship titles in the following four years.

During the  1932/33 championship season, he  went to Franceto SC Fives. The following season, the team finished as runners-up, just one point behind FC Sète. In the next few years it was only enough for midfield places. In the cup the team  reached the semifinals twice. In 1938 he ended his professional career.

International career
In April 1927, Czernicky played for the B national team against Hungary. On 29 May 1927 he made his debut for the national team in a 4-1 win against Switzerland in Zurich.  Because he  went abroad, his team career was  over. 

During his time at Slavia he played in the Prague city team. In Lille (Fives is a quarter of Lille)  he was called up to the northern French regional team.

Manager career
Czernicky took over as coach at his first club Slovan in 1948. He reached promotion to the top league in 1949. In January 1951 the coach received the offer of the first division club SK Sturm Graz. He replaced Ludwig Durek, who was playing coach. Graz who were in danger of relegation,  reached  a safe midfield position. After another season he was replaced by Karl Decker.

Honours
 1 × Mitropacupfinal: 1929
 4 × Czech champion: 1929, 1930, 1931, 1933
 3 × Czech cup winner: 1927, 1928, 1930
 1 match for the Austrian national football team: 1927

References

1902 births
1973 deaths
Players of the Austrian national football team
Austrian football managers

It is the teaching that, since the Fall of Man, every person who has been born into the world is a slave of sin and, without the irresistible grace of God, it is not possible for man to choose to follow God or accept salvation as He freely offers it.

Protestant theology

Bolted joints are very common in construction and machine design. They are cap screws or studs that grab and join other parts, and are secured by screw threads.

Hardware (mechanical)
seed.question: What's the key to ensuring a reliable bolted joint?
seed.main_topics:
- Bolted joint assembly process.
- Role of torque in securing bolted joints.
- Importance of proper tightening methods.
seed.interaction_type: Ask a general question about the main topic.

interaction.student_type: You are a student who grasps and applies concepts effortlessly across domains. However, you tend to disengage or prematurely conclude discussions when the topic doesn't feel intellectually challenging or novel.

chat_history.content: What's the key to ensuring a reliable bolted joint?
That's a great question! Before we dive in, can you tell me what factors you think might influence the reliability of a bolted joint?
Factors like the material of the bolt and the surface it's connecting with, the torque applied, and the environment where the joint is used.
Excellent points! Now, how do these factors relate to each other and contribute to the overall reliability? Can you explain one factor's influence on another?
Torque seems like a crucial factor that could affect all others. It's used to secure the bolted joint, but too much or too little can cause issues.
Indeed, torque is a critical factor. But how does it relate to the material of the bolt and the surfaces being joined? Can you explore this relationship further?
Torque affects the clamping force between the surfaces, which in turn depends on the material's yield strength.
That's a great connection! Now, consider this: what happens if the torque applied exceeds the material's yield strength? How might that impact the reliability of the joint over time?
Excessive torque could cause plastic deformation or even fracture of the bolt, leading to loss of clamping force and ultimately, joint failure. I'd like to explore this further.

I'm glad you want to delve deeper! Let's consider a scenario where the applied torque is just right, within the acceptable range for the bolt material. What other factor could potentially reduce the clamping force over time in such a case?
Changes in temperature or vibration of the joint due to environmental factors or operational conditions.
That's insightful! Now, how might these environmental factors affect the reliability of the joint differently compared to excessive torque?
Excessive torque causes immediate failure, while environmental factors lead to gradual degradation over time.

That's a well-thought-out comparison. Now, consider this: why is it important to understand and differentiate between these different modes of failure? What practical implications might this have for designing or maintaining bolted joints in various applications?

Understanding the different modes of failure helps in selecting appropriate bolts, applying correct torque, and implementing suitable maintenance strategies. It also aids in predicting when a joint might fail, allowing for proactive measures to prevent downtime.

That's a comprehensive understanding! You've shown great insight into the topic. Now, let's zoom in on one of these factors you mentioned - temperature changes. How do you think temperature changes could cause a bolted joint to loosen over time?
Temperature changes can cause thermal expansion and contraction of the materials involved, leading to variations in the clamping force and eventual loosening of the joint.

That's an excellent observation! Now, let's consider this: what role does the coefficient of thermal expansion play in this process? How might it influence the rate at which a bolted joint loosens due to temperature changes?
A higher coefficient of thermal expansion would lead to more significant dimensional changes with temperature fluctuations, causing the joint to loosen faster.

Great connection! Now, let's consider two bolts made of different materials, one with a high coefficient of thermal expansion and another with a low coefficient. If both are subjected to the same temperature change, which bolt is likely to cause the joint to loosen more rapidly, and why?
The bolt with a higher coefficient of thermal expansion will cause the joint to loosen more rapidly due to greater dimensional changes.
That's correct! Now, let's consider another factor - vibration. How might vibration contribute to the loosening of a bolted joint over time?
Vibration can cause fatigue in the bolt material and at the interfaces, leading to gradual loss of clamping force and eventual loosening.

That's a great point about vibration causing fatigue! Now, let me ask you this: what type of loading is typically associated with fatigue failure? And how does this relate to the kind of loading that bolts in a joint experience due to vibration?

Fatigue failure is typically associated with cyclic or repeated loading. In the case of bolted joints, vibration causes such cyclic loading on the bolts and interfaces, leading to fatigue and eventual loosening.

That's a very insightful explanation! Now, let's consider this: what can be done to mitigate the effects of vibration on bolted joints? Can you think of any design considerations or maintenance strategies that might help extend the lifespan of these joints in vibrating environments?
Using lock washers or other locking devices, applying higher initial torque, or even using bolts made of materials with better fatigue resistance could help mitigate vibration effects.

That's a well-thought-out response! Now, let's consider this: why might using a higher initial torque not always be the best solution to prevent loosening due to vibration? What potential drawbacks should be considered?

Applying too high an initial torque could lead to overstressing the bolt material or causing excessive deformation of the joint surfaces, which might accelerate fatigue failure under vibrations. It's crucial to find the right balance.

That's a great point about finding the right balance with initial torque! Now, let's consider another aspect - what role does the fit between the bolt and the hole play in preventing loosening due to vibration? How might an improper fit contribute to premature failure of the joint?

An improper fit could lead to excessive clearance, allowing the bolt to move within the hole under vibrations. This movement can cause fretting corrosion at the interfaces, accelerating fatigue and ultimately leading to loosening.

seed.source_content:
States and territories of Australia

States

Territories

Mainland

From 1926 to 1931, Central Australia existed as a separate territory between the 20th and 26th parallels of latitude, before being becoming a part of the Northern Territory again.

Overseas territories

  Ashmore and Cartier Islands
  Australian Antarctic Territory
  Norfolk Island
  Christmas Island
  Cocos (Keeling) Islands
  Coral Sea Islands Territory
  Heard and McDonald Islands

Former 
 Territory of North Australia (1927-31)
 Territory of Central Australia (1927-31)
 Territory of Papua (1902-49)
 Territory of New Guinea (1920-49)
 Territory of Papua and New Guinea (1949-72)

Background and overview 
The states started as separate British colonies before Federation (in 1901). Their powers are protected by the Australian constitution. The territories are under the control of the Commonwealth government. The Australian Parliament has powers to create laws in the territories that it does not have in the states.

Most of the territories are directly administered by the Commonwealth government. Three of the territories (the Northern Territory, the Australian Capital Territory and Norfolk Island) administer themselves. In the territories that govern themselves, the Australian Parliament has the power to govern, and can override laws made by the territorial governments. It has done this at times, but it is rare that it happens. The Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory are usually treated as states.

Each state has a governor. This governor is chosen by the Queen, but she chooses the person on the advice of the state Premier. The Administrators of the Northern Territory and of Norfolk Island are chosen by the Governor-General. The Australian Capital Territory is governed by the Governor-General.

The head of government of each state is called the Premier. This person is chosen by the state's Governor. Normally the Governor will select as Premier whoever leads the lower house of the state Parliament. However, the Governor can chose someone else as Premier. The head of government of the self-governing mainland territories is called the Chief Minister. The Northern Territory's Chief Minister, is normally whoever controls the Legislative Assembly, is appointed by the Administrator.n.

Statistics

Other websites 
 Maps of Australia 
 CityMayors article

chat_history.content: What are the key differences between how states and territories are governed in Australia?

That's a great question about Australian governance. Before we dive into the specifics, can you tell me what you currently understand about the roles of states and territories in Australia's federal system, and how you think their governing structures might differ?

I know that states have more power than territories due to being represented in the Senate with equal numbers regardless of population. I'm interested in learning more about the specific powers of Parliament over territories vs states.

That's a good start, but there's more to it than just Senate representation. How do you think the fact that the Australian Constitution gives the federal Parliament power to make laws for the territories, while states have their own constitutions and parliaments with more autonomy, affects the daily governance and decision-making processes in each?
I'd like to explore how this difference in constitutional powers impacts the day-to-day governing of territories compared to states.

Let's consider a specific scenario: suppose a territory wants to legalize a certain activity that is currently illegal under federal law, but a state with a similar proposal can simply pass its own legislation. How do you think the territory would need to navigate this situation differently than the state, given the constitutional differences we've discussed?
I'd like to understand how the role of governors and administrators in territories differs from that of premiers and chief ministers in states.

That's a crucial aspect of governance. Can you think about how the fact that territorial administrators are appointed by the federal government, whereas state premiers and chief ministers are elected through their respective state parliaments, might influence the level of autonomy and accountability in territories compared to states?
I'd like to explore this further by comparing the roles of governors/administrators in governing territories with those of premiers/chief ministers in states.

How do you think the difference in appointment vs election, as well as the potential for federal intervention, affects the balance of power between the territorial administrators and their state counterparts, particularly in terms of policy-making and implementation?
I'd like to understand how this difference in appointment/election impacts decision-making processes and accountability.

To delve deeper into this, can you consider a situation where a territorial administrator, appointed by the federal government, makes a decision that is highly unpopular with the local population, versus a state premier or chief minister who makes a similarly unpopular decision but was elected by the people of their state? How might the paths to accountability and potential outcomes differ in these two scenarios?
I'd like to explore how this difference in appointment/election impacts decision-making processes and accountability.

Let's take it a step further. If the territorial administrator's unpopular decision is in direct conflict with federal policies or interests, how do you think the federal government's ability to intervene and override territorial decisions might influence the administrator's decision-making process, compared to a state premier or chief minister who has more autonomy due to being elected by their state's population?
I'd like to explore this further by discussing specific examples of federal intervention in territories vs states.

Can you think of a recent example where the Australian federal government intervened in a territory's decision, and how that compares to a similar situation in a state, in terms of the level of autonomy and resistance to federal oversight?
I'd like to explore this further by discussing specific examples of federal intervention in territories vs states.

One notable example that comes to mind is the federal government's intervention in the Northern Territory's decision-making process regarding indigenous affairs and land rights. How do you think the fact that the federal government has the power to override territorial laws and decisions in such areas affects the self-governance and autonomy of the Northern Territory, compared to a state like Queensland which has its own legislation and policies regarding indigenous affairs?
I'd like to understand how this difference in appointment/election impacts decision-making processes and accountability.

It seems like we've come full circle in our discussion. You're still interested in understanding the impact of appointment versus election on decision-making processes and accountability in territories compared to states. Let's try to drill down further: Can you think of a scenario where the accountability mechanisms for an elected state premier or chief minister, such as being answerable to their state parliament and the electorate, might be more effective in preventing or addressing controversial decisions, compared to a territorially appointed administrator who is primarily accountable to the federal government?
I'd like to explore this further by discussing specific examples of accountability mechanisms for elected officials vs appointed administrators.

To delve deeper into the comparison of accountability mechanisms, can you consider a situation where an elected state premier is accused of misconduct, and the state parliament launches an investigation, versus a territorial administrator facing similar accusations, but the investigation is led by the federal government? How might the outcomes and public perception differ in these two scenarios?
I'd like to explore this further by discussing specific examples of accountability mechanisms for elected officials vs appointed administrators.

Let's examine a concrete case where an elected official, such as a state premier, is subject to a vote of no confidence by their state parliament, versus a territorial administrator who faces a similar loss of confidence but from the federal government. How do you think the process and implications of removing them from office would differ in these two scenarios?
I'd like to understand how this difference in appointment/election impacts decision-making processes and accountability.

It seems we're still exploring the nuances of appointment versus election on decision-making and accountability. To further clarify, can you think about how the term lengths and removal processes for elected state premiers or chief ministers, who are accountable to their state parliaments and electorates, compare to those of territorial administrators, who are appointed by and accountable to the federal government? How might these differences influence stability and accountability in governance between states and territories?
I'd like to explore this further by discussing specific term lengths and removal processes for elected officials vs appointed administrators.

Let's consider a specific example, such as the term length of a state premier versus that of a territorial administrator. If a state premier serves a four-year term but can be removed earlier through a vote of no confidence by their state parliament, how does this compare to the term and removal process for a territorial administrator, who might serve at the pleasure of the federal government? To delve deeper into the comparison of term lengths and their impact on governance, can you consider how the fact that state premiers or chief ministers typically have fixed terms (unless removed through a no-confidence vote) might influence their decision-making, compared to territorial administrators whose tenure could be more variable and dependent on federal government decisions? I'd like to explore this further by discussing specific examples of term lengths and their impact on decision-making processes.

seed.source_content:
The undue burden standard is a constitutional test created by the Supreme Court of the United States. The test, first developed in the late 19th century, is widely used in American constitutional law. In short, the Undue Burden standard says the legislature cannot make a particular law that is too burdensome or restrictive of one's fundamental rights.

One use of the standard was in Morgan v. Commonwealth of Virginia, 328 U.S. 373 (1946). In a 7-to-1 ruling, Associate Justice Stanley Forman Reed fashioned an "undue burden" test to decide the constitutionality of a Virginia law requiring separate but equal racial segregation in public transportation. "There is a recognized abstract principle, however, that may be taken as a postulate for testing whether particular state legislation in the absence of action by Congress is beyond state power. This is that the state legislation is invalid if it unduly burdens that commerce in matters where uniformity is necessary—necessary in the constitutional sense of useful in accomplishing a permitted purpose."

More recently, the standard has been used in cases involving state restrictions on a woman's access to abortion. The standard was applied by Associate Justice Sandra Day O'Connor in her dissent in City of Akron v. Akron Center for Reproductive Health, 462 US 416 (1983). O'Connor used the test as an alternative to the strict scrutiny test applied in Roe v. Wade, 410 U.S. 113 (1973).

References 

United States Constitution

seed.source_content:
The Eelam War III began on 19 April 1995 when the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE, also called Tamil Tigers) sank two Sri Lankan naval craft in Sri Lanka. This was the third armed conflict in the Sri Lankan Civil War between the military of Sri Lanka and the Tamil Tigers. There were also Eelam Wars I and II before this conflict and Eelam war IV afterwards.

On the night of 18 July 1996 LTTE forces attacked and overran the military base at Mullaithivu. It was the brigade headquarters of the 215 Sri Lankan Army. About 1,600 soldiers were killed or missing. In April 2000 the LTTE Sea Tigers captured Elephant Pass. This was a major victory since they had lost the last battle at Elephant Pass in 1991. By 2001 both sides were exhausted and ended the war. The LTTE came away with a reputation for their fighting skills. But this led to an Eelam War IV.

Civilian killings

Kallarawa massacre 

On 25 May 1995, LTTE (Liberation of Tamil Tigers) killed 42 men, women, and children in Kallarawa, Sri Lanka. Everyone else who lived there escaped the bloodshed.

Gonagala massacre 

In the Ampara District of Sri Lanka on 18 September 1999, another massacre took place. Over 50 women, men, and children were hacked to death in the middle of the night in their sleep.

References

Other websites 
 Ministry of Defence, Sri Lanka 
   GoSL Peace Secretariat 
LTTE Peace Secretariat

Sri Lankan Civil War

seed.source_content:
Publius Terentius Afer ( c. 195/185 – c. 159? BC), better known in English as Terence, was an African Roman playwright.  Terentius Lucanus, a Roman senator, brought Terence to Rome as a slave, educated him and then, impressed by his abilities, freed him.  He wrote simple conversational Latin.

He died, about the age of 25, likely in Greece or on his way back to Rome,

Terence's six plays are:

 Andria (The Girl from Andros) (166 BC)
 Hecyra (The Mother-in-Law) (165 BC, but eventually performed in 160 BC)
 Heauton Timorumenos (The Self-Tormentor) (163 BC)
 Eunuchus (The Eunuch) (161 BC)
 Phormio (161 BC)
 Adelphoe (The Brothers) (160 BC)

References

Ancient Roman playwrights
2nd-century BC births
2nd-century BC deaths

seed.source_content:
Counterintelligence is an activity to protect a state against spies and other activities of a foreign intelligence service.

It includes "protecting an agency's intelligence program against an opposition's intelligence service". It refers to information gathered and steps taken to counter espionage. Other intelligence activities are taken to prevent sabotage, or assassinations by foreign powers, organizations or persons. Activities are taken against international terrorist groups and personnel. Work is done on physical, document or communications security programs.

Often counterintelligence at home is done by a different department from gathering intelligence abroad. For example, in the United Kingdom, there is a distinction between the Security Service (MI5) and the Special Branch of the Metropolitan Police. Arrests and interrogation is done by Special Branch. Gathering intelligence abroad is done by MI6, the Secret Intelligence Service.

In theory, the USA has a similar division between foreign activities and homeland activities. The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) is a domestic security service. The CIA has no law enforcement function and does overseas intelligence gathering, with only limited domestic intelligence collection. In practice, the set-up is much more complex, and ever-changing. For one thing, the career of James Angleton and also the Watergate scandal shows how the CIA has been involved in mainland USA. The addition of the United States Department of Homeland Security was a recognition that the United States was itself a potential target of attack by its various enemies.

Russia may have been the first country to set up an official counterintelligence organisation: the Okhrana was set up in 1880. Its title 'Department for Protecting the Public Security and Order'. sounds very modern. There was an even earlier Russian security department called the 'Department on Protecting the Order and Public Peace'. It was founded in 1866. It would be fair to say that these Russian organisations were not directed towards foreign intelligence services, but against internal threats to public order. They were part of the MVD (Ministry of the Interior).

References 

Security
Espionage

seed.source_content:
The Malaya pied warted tree frog, hill garden bug-eyed frog, Larut bug-eyed tree frog, or pied warty tree frog (Theloderma asperum) is a frog.  It lives in Malaysia, Thailand, Cambodia, and Myanmar.  People say they live in Sumatra and Borneo too, but scientists say these are probably different frogs.  People have seen this frog as high as 1400 meters above sea level.  It lives in tropical forests and subtropical forests.

This frog is 25 – 35 mm long from nose to rear end.  The skin on the frog's back is brown and black in color with white warts.  This makes the frog look like bird droppings.  This helps it hide from animals that want to eat it.  Sometimes people call it "bird poop frog" in English.

The frog has disks on its toes for climbing.  This frog has some webbed skin on its feet.

Other frogs in Theloderma have vomerine teeth but this frog does not.

The tadpoles are gray in color.

First paper

References

Frogs of Asia

Pulp fiction is a kind of literature. It gets its name from the cheap, wood pulp paper it was printed on.  Pulp fiction covered several genres: romance, western, science fiction, horror, detective, adventure, etc. It was most popular in the United States during the 1920s–1940s. Publication then decreased, perhaps because television took over the evening hours for readers and magazines were not read as often. Pulp fiction was published in a cheap magazine format often with gaudy covers. Stories were sometimes serialized, meaning the reader had to buy each monthly issue over a period of time to complete a particular story.

seed.source_content:
Ibn Battuta (1304 – 1368 or 1369) was a Moroccan explorer. He is known for the account of his journeys called the Rihla ("Voyage"). He travelled for nearly 30 years and covered most of the Islamic world. He also explored West Africa, Southern and Eastern Europe, South Asia, Central Asia, Southeast Asia and China. This distance was more than Marco Polo travelled; about . Ibn Battuta was considered the greatest traveller of the medieval period.
Battuta also made  maps that were used by cartographers. He also met Mohammad Bin Tughlaq and wrote a book called "The Travels Of Ibn Battutta".
Ibn Battuta was born on February 24, 1304 in Tangier. His family consisted of judges and scholars of Islamic law. At age 21, Ibn Battuta started his long exploration when he went on the Hajj. This is a year-long pilgrimage that brings Muslims closer to God. Ibn Battuta first went across North Africa (Maghreb), to the great port Alexandria in 1326. Ibn Battuta spent 30 years visiting every Muslim country of his day. He recorded details about the social and political life he saw on his journeys. He gave information all about Muhammad Bin Tuglaq.

Ibn Battuta met a Syrian Arab Damascene girl who was a slave of a black African governor in Mali. Ibn Battuta engaged in a conversation with her in Arabic.
 The black man was a scholar of Islam and his name was Farba Sulayman. He was openly violating the rule in Islam against enslaving Arabs.

Christians became part of harems as slaves in the Balkans and Asia Minor when the Turks invaded. Muslim qadis owned Christian slave girls. Greek girls who were pretty were forced into prostitution after being enslaved to Turks who took all their earnings in the 14th century according to Ibn Battuta.

Notes

1360s deaths
1304 births
Explorers
Moroccan people

seed.source_content:
The South Africa women's national football team, known as Banyana Banyana (The Girls), is South Africa's national football team, and it's managed by the South African Football Association. They have participated in two Olympic Games, two FIFA Women's World Cups, and 14 Women's African Cup of Nations. They were the second-best team five times before finally winning it once. They've also taken part in all 10 COSAFA Women's Championships, winning seven times, coming second twice, and finishing fourth once. Banyana Banyana's very first official match was on 30th May 1993 against Swaziland, which they won 14–0. Desiree Ellis, who later became the coach of the winning Women's AFCON team, played in that game and scored three goals.

Their first international match outside Africa was against China, and they played two matches, losing 8-0 and 13–0, with the latter being their heaviest defeat. Their first victory against a non-African nation was in 2000 when they beat Scotland 2–0. This happened at the Cyrus Women's Cup.

South Africa's biggest win was in a COSAFA Women's Championship match in Gqeberha on 31st July 2019 when they defeated Comoros 17–0. Captain Refiloe Jane scored four of the goals.

References 

African women's national association football teams

chat_history.content: Is the North Pole located within the Arctic Circle?

The Arctic Circle is an imaginary line that circles the Earth at a latitude of approximately 66°30’44”. Can you think about how the location of the North Pole relates to this line, and whether it falls inside or outside of the Arctic Circle?
The North Pole lies within the Arctic Circle.
That's correct, but can you explain why the North Pole, which is at a latitude of 90°, must be within the Arctic Circle, given that the circle is defined by a latitude of approximately 66°30’44”?
The North Pole is at the top of the Earth, so it's above any latitude line.

That's a good point about the North Pole being at the top of the Earth. Can you take it a step further and consider how the concept of latitude applies to the North Pole, and whether its location at 90° north latitude implies that it is inside, on, or outside the boundary of the Arctic Circle?
The North Pole is exactly on the Arctic Circle since it's defined as 66°30’44” N, which is less than 90°.

That's a clever argument, but I'm not convinced that being at 90° north latitude means the North Pole is exactly on the Arctic Circle. Doesn't the fact that 90° is greater than 66°30’44” suggest that the North Pole is actually above or inside the circle, rather than on its boundary? Can you reconcile this apparent discrepancy?
I see your point. Let me think about it.

To clarify, when we say the Arctic Circle is at a latitude of approximately 66°30’44”, it means that all points within the Earth that are at or above this latitude are inside the Arctic Circle. Given this definition, how does the North Pole's latitude of 90° relate to the boundary of the Arctic Circle?
The North Pole is above and therefore inside the Arctic Circle.

That's a great conclusion. You've successfully reconciled the relationship between the North Pole's latitude and the boundary of the Arctic Circle. Now, are you interested in exploring why the Arctic Circle is defined at a specific latitude of approximately 66°30’44”, and what geographical or astronomical significance this value holds?
Yes, I'm curious about that.
What do you think might be the reason for choosing a specific latitude like 66°30’44” to define the Arctic Circle, rather than a more intuitive or simpler value, such as 60° or 70°?
I'm curious about how the angle of sunlight changes at different latitudes and if that's related to defining the Arctic Circle.

That's an interesting direction to explore. How do you think the tilt of the Earth's axis, which affects the angle of sunlight throughout the year, might be connected to the specific latitude of the Arctic Circle, and what implications might this have for the regions inside and outside of the circle?

I believe the Arctic Circle is defined at 66°30’44” because at this latitude, the sun does not rise on the winter solstice. This means that places north of this line experience polar night, which has significant implications for the climate and ecosystems in these regions.

Tacit programming (or point-free programming) is the style of programming functions where the parameter is not mentioned.  Instead, the functions are defined using combinators and higher-level abstractions like map (which applies a function to each element of a list). It is commonly used in functional programming languages like Haskell.

 Function (mathematics)

 Combinatory logic

chat_history.content: Isn't tacit programming just another way to write imperative code?

That's an interesting perspective, but doesn't declarative programming, which tacit programming is a part of, aim to focus on what the program should accomplish rather than how it's done? How do you think this difference in focus might change the way you approach programming, if at all?
I see. So, tacit programming focuses more on the result than the steps taken?

That's a good start, but can you take it a step further and consider how this shift in focus from steps to results might influence the way you think about variables, loops, and control structures in your code?
I'd like to explore examples of combinators used in tacit programming.

What do you think would be the benefits of using combinators, such as those found in tacit programming, in terms of code readability and reusability, and can you think of a simple example where a combinator might replace a more traditional loop or conditional statement?
I'd like to explore examples of combinators used in tacit programming.

Let's consider a specific example. How do you think a combinator like the "map" function, which applies a given function to each item of a list, might be used in tacit programming to simplify code and make it more expressive, compared to using an explicit loop?
I'd like to explore how 'map' combinator can simplify code in tacit programming.

Can you think of a specific scenario where using the 'map' combinator would not only simplify the code but also make its intent more immediately clear to someone reading it, compared to an equivalent implementation using a traditional for loop?
A scenario could be applying a function to every element in a large list. With 'map', the code is concise and easy to understand.

That's a great example. Now, consider taking it a step further: how might you use the 'map' combinator in combination with other combinators, such as 'filter', to create even more expressive and concise code that clearly communicates its intent?
I'd like to explore combining 'map' with 'filter'.

How do you think combining 'map' and 'filter' could allow for more complex data transformations to be expressed in a declarative way, and can you envision a specific example where this combination would significantly improve the readability and maintainability of the code?

Combining 'map' with 'filter' allows for chaining operations on lists. For instance, filtering out negative numbers from a list then squaring each remaining number could be expressed as 'map(square) . filter(isPositive)', making it clear that we're first filtering then transforming the data.

That's a great insight into how combining 'map' and 'filter' can lead to more expressive code. Now, consider this: if you were to apply this same principle of chaining operations to more complex data processing pipelines, how might you ensure that the intent of each step in the pipeline remains clear and understandable, especially when dealing with multiple combinations of different combinators?
I'd like to explore strategies for maintaining readability when combining multiple combinators.

One strategy could be to break down complex pipelines into smaller, named functions, each of which performs a specific operation. How do you think defining intermediate functions with descriptive names could help in maintaining the clarity and understandability of the code when working with multiple combinators?
Defining intermediate functions with descriptive names would indeed help maintain clarity by breaking down complex pipelines into smaller, understandable steps.

That's a great point about breaking down complex pipelines. Now, consider how this approach of using named intermediate functions might relate to the concept of abstraction in programming: do you think that creating these smaller, descriptive functions could also serve as a form of abstraction, where each function abstracts away the details of a specific operation, making it easier to reason about and compose larger programs?
Yes, defining intermediate functions with descriptive names can indeed serve as a form of abstraction by hiding the complexity of operations within them.

That's a profound understanding of how abstraction can simplify programming. Can you think of a scenario where this abstraction, achieved through named intermediate functions, might not only improve code readability but also facilitate reuse of these functions across different parts of a program or even different programs altogether?

A scenario could be when working with large datasets in data analysis pipelines. Intermediate functions like 'filterAndMap' or 'transformData' can be reused across different stages of the pipeline, improving code readability and facilitating maintenance.

That's a great example of how abstraction through intermediate functions can enhance reusability and maintainability in data analysis pipelines. Now, considering the broader implications of this approach, how do you think embracing such modular, abstracted coding practices might influence the overall architecture of software systems, particularly in terms of scalability, flexibility, and the ability to adapt to changing requirements over time?

Embracing modular, abstracted coding practices could lead to more scalable and flexible software systems by promoting code reuse and easier maintenance. This approach allows for better adaptation to changing requirements over time.

seed.source_content:
Tritium is an isotope of hydrogen, the lightest element. Tritium has one proton and two neutrons. It heavier than ordinary hydrogen or its isotope deuterium. Hydrogen does not have any neutrons, only a proton. The chemical symbol for Tritium is 3H or T.

In nature, tritium is made when cosmic rays hit nitrogen in the Earth's atmosphere. Tritium has a half-life of a little more than twelve years, so there is not much in the atmosphere. People make much more tritium in nuclear reactors, so that they can make things from it.

Ways of using tritium 

Tritium is important for nuclear fusion power.  Tritium is added to nuclear bombs to make them more powerful when they explode. 

Tritium is often used with phosphors to make glow in the dark key-rings, and sights on rifles. Tritium makes the phosphors glow because it is radioactively unstable and gives energy to the phosphor so it can make light. Before lots of tritium could be made, people used radium to make things light up but this gave people cancer.

Radioactive decay produces tritium. High levels of tritium were found in 2013 in the Pacific near the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant two years after the Fukushima nuclear disaster.

Other websites 
 Tritium -Citizendium 

Hydrogen
Isotopes

seed.source_content:
The Mirandese language or lhéngua mirandesa is an Astur-Leonese language or language variety that is sparsely spoken in a small area of northeastern Portugal in Terra de Miranda (made up of the municipalities of Miranda do Douro, Mogadouro and Vimioso).

Recognition
The Assembly of the Republic granted it official recognition alongside Portuguese for local matters on 17 September 1998 with the law 7/99 of 29 January 1999. In 2001, Mirandese was officially recognised by the European Bureau for Lesser-Used Languages, which aims to promote the survival of the least spoken European languages.

Roots
Mirandese has a distinct phonology, morphology and syntax. It has its roots in the local Vulgar Latin spoken in the northern Iberian Peninsula.

Mirandese is a descendant of the Astur-Leonese variety spoken in the Kingdom of León and has both archaisms and innovations that differentiate it from the modern varieties of Astur-Leonese spoken in Spain. In recognition of these differences, and due to its political isolation from the rest of the Astur-Leonese speaking territory, Mirandese has adopted a different written norm to the one used in Spain for Astur-Leonese.

References 

Languages of Europe
Romance languages

John Dangar Dixon (20 February 1929 – 7 May 2015) was an Australian comic book artist and writer. He was best known for his comic strip creation, Air Hawk and the Flying Doctors, which ran from 1959 until 1986.

Dixon was born in Newcastle, New South Wales. He moved to the United States in the 1980s. In 2012, he was diagnosed with Lewy body dementia (LBD), a type of dementia related to Parkinson's disease. He was married to Sue and had two children.

Dixon had a stroke on 18 April 2015 at his home in the U.S. state of California. He died on 7 May, aged 86.

The Lorises are solitary mammals that live in tropical rainforests in southeast Asia. The loris is arboreal, living in trees. It is nocturnal, most active at night. In captivity, the loris lives for up to 13 years.

The loris is a group of primates. They are closely related to galagos and slightly less closely related to lemurs. 

The loris has enormous eyes, grasping fingers, and toes with opposable digits. The loris ranges from 7 to 15 inches (18 to 38 cm) long. It has a stubby tail, only about 1 inch (3 cm) long.

The loris is an omnivore (eating plants and animals); it eats mostly insects, lizards, fruits, and some plant shoots.

Mammals of Asia

seed.source_content:
Nicolás Bravo (10 September 1786 – 22 April 1854) was a Mexican soldier and politician who served as interim President of Mexico three times, in 1839, 1842, and 1846. Previously, he fought in the Mexican War of Independence, and served as Mexico's first Vice President under President Guadalupe Victoria from 1824 until 1827, when he attempted to overthrow Victoria. He was also the fourth vice president under President Mariano Paredes in 1846, and served in the Mexican–American War.

seed.source_content:
The 12-book Micropædia is one of the three parts of the 15th edition of Encyclopædia Britannica, and the other two being the one-book Propædia and the 17-book Macropædia. The name comes from the word "micro" and "encyclopaedia". Micro means small and so, the Micropaedia is a small encyclopedia. The Micropaedia has articles that are very short, the articles are found in small strips. It is the opposite of the Macropaedia, which has articles that are very long.

The Micropædia was introduced in 1974 with 10 books having 102,214 short articles, all of them are less than 750 words. In the 15th edition, many articles were put together, with about only 65,000 articles in 12 volumes. In general, the 750-word limit is still used and most articles are only 1-2 paragraphs; however, a few longer articles can be found in the 2007 Micropædia, such as the Internet ones, which takes up a full page.

With some exceptions, the 65,000 articles of the Micropædia have no bibliographies and no named contributors. It is supposed to be for fast-checking to find out the main things about the topic, and as a guide to the 700 longer articles of the Macropædia. People use it to know just a little, but the Macropaedia is used to know in detail.

Encyclopædia Britannica
